title: Kalighat painting
summary: Kalighat painting, also known as Kalighat Patachitra, is a distinctive Indian painting style originating in 19th-century Kolkata, West Bengal. Practiced by "patuas" near the Kalighat Kali Temple, these paintings feature bold outlines, vibrant colors, and minimal backgrounds. They depicted Hindu deities, mythological tales, and scenes from everyday life, serving as a visual record of 19th and early 20th-century socio-cultural transitions. The style reached its peak during this period. The Victoria and Albert Museum in London houses the world's largest collection, comprising 645 pieces. The exact origin date is debated among art historians, though material evidence suggests the first half of the 19th century, coinciding with the temple's establishment.
key_points: Originated in 19th century Kolkata, West Bengal, near the Kalighat Kali Temple.
Characterized by bold outlines, vibrant colors, and minimal backgrounds.
Depicts Hindu mythological stories, gods, goddesses, and everyday life scenes.
Served as a socio-cultural record during a transitional period in the 19th and early 20th centuries.
The Victoria and Albert Museum in London holds the world's largest collection of Kalighat paintings.
The exact origin date (early 19th century) is a subject of historical debate among art critics and historians.
timeline: 19th century: Kalighat painting originated in Kolkata.
First half of 19th century: Material evidence suggests this period for the paintings.
First or second quarter of 19th century: Emergence coincides with the establishment of the present-day Kali temple at Kalighat.
1830s to 1930s: Period of creation and collection for artworks housed in the Victoria and Albert Museum.
19th and early 20th century: The Kalighat Pat reached its pinnacle.

current_status: Kalighat painting is a recognized and studied style of Indian painting. Major collections are preserved in museums, notably the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. Its precise origins remain a subject of ongoing historical and art critical debate.
future_prospects: Future prospects include continued academic research and historical analysis regarding its origins and impact. There is potential for further preservation efforts for existing museum collections. Increased scholarly interest in its role as a socio-cultural document is also likely.
